This looks better just from the fact that it isn't relying on toString(); it probably doesn't change the functionality, though, since from the rest of the code in that file, it seems all these files are being created with absolute paths.

Agree, if the paths were all absolute to begin with, this is a more robust way of doing the same thing. I don't know if they were all absolute in fact (in which case the original code wouldn't quite work); it is a good bet. Either way +1
Okay I pulled this in. This was just a rename.
That merge makes the GitHub diffs really unclean, one sec and I'll make it a nicer clean merge

@srowen if you have time, mind submitting a PR with just the first change? I can also cherry-pick it manually but it's a bit nicer to go through the normal mechanisms.
Okay cool, this is just a minor improvement.

I'll say it again: When you are working on preparing a PR, you're better off rebasing than merging.

within a clone of your github repo:

git pull --rebase git@github.com:apache/spark.git master
git push origin +YourBranchName
Jenkins, test this please. This looks good to me, pending tests (I'd also like to test this locally).
Sure I just reverted and force-pushed the branch with just the original commit

Fixed up with an unfortunate force push.  I typically use merges for these sorts of things but forgot how bad they appear in GitHub.  Will remember to use rebase for GitHub projects in the future.

Any comments on the Java/Python bridges?

@pwendell I already took care of this in #701
Thanks for submitting this. Do you have a link to the Scala compiler/collection library ticket that impacted this?

Thanks for submitting this - but considering this is a low level building block collection and not meant to be used as a general collection library, and the method's name itself is very obvious that it doesn't do resizing, I am not sure if it is worth changing them at this point.
Why do closures with return fail?
Do you mind closing this if it is no longer necessary? Thanks.
